events.title: Gregorian Calendar Adoption Begins
events.description: The Gregorian calendar was first introduced by Pope Gregory XIII, beginning on October 5, 1582. In countries adopting it, the date jumped to October 15, 1582, to correct the drift of the Julian calendar.
events.significance: This calendar reform corrected inaccuracies in the Julian calendar and is the calendar system still in use today worldwide.

events.title: First Flight of the Bell X-1
events.description: Chuck Yeager piloted the Bell X-1 rocket plane and became the first person to break the sound barrier, exceeding the speed of sound in level flight.
events.significance: This event marked a significant breakthrough in aviation technology and paved the way for supersonic flight.

events.title: End of the Second Vatican Council's First Session
events.description: The first session of the Second Vatican Council concluded, initiating reforms in the Roman Catholic Church, including liturgical changes and relations with other religions.
events.significance: The Council led to significant modernization of the Catholic Church and influenced Christian practice worldwide.

events.title: Jimi Hendrix Dies
events.description: Legendary American rock guitarist Jimi Hendrix passed away in London at the age of 27.
events.significance: Hendrix's death marked the loss of one of the most influential electric guitarists and cultural icons of the 20th century.

events.title: Richard Stallman Announces the GNU Project
events.description: Richard Stallman publicly announced the GNU Project, which aimed to create a free Unix-like operating system, forming the foundation for open-source software movements.
events.significance: The project led to the development of free software and had a lasting impact on software development and distribution models.
